name: Advanced Lists
pages: These patterns seem to represent common operations I perform on lists. Though these are perfectly possible to do with normal $(l:patterns/lists)List Manipulation/$, it often requires more effort. Perhaps Nature willed them into existence to better understand what I'm doing... or perhaps they are my own invention?

pages.text: Rotates the list leftward: an argument of 1 moves the first item of the list to the end. Negative numbers allow rotating the list rightward.
Selects the first few elements from the input list. If the number is negative, selects the last few elements instead.
Drops the first few elements from the input list; the dual to $(l:addon/hexic/lists2#hexic:take/count)$(action)Retention Distillation/$.
Selects from the list only elements corresponding to the given indices. Unlike $(l:patterns/lists#hexcasting:index)$(action)Selection Distillation/$, this cannot reorder or duplicate iotas.
Drops from the list iotas at the given indices. All other iotas are kept in the same order as the input.
Creates a list of the indices for which True is present. For example, [True, False, True] becomes [0, 2]. I can also mix bools and ints in the input list.
Adds each index to the list based on the value. For example, [1, 2, 3] becomes [0, 1, 1, 2, 2, 2]. Zero or negative numbers do not appear at all.
Calculates the outer product of two lists. The resulting list has an entry for every possible pairing between the input lists.
Calculates the inner product of two lists. If the two lists were arranged side-by-side, the resulting list has one entry for every row (unpaired elements are skipped).
Extracts an iota from the given list, and breaks the list apart around it. Returns all items before the iota, all items after the iota, and finally the iota itself.
Discards iotas from the given list unless they satisfy the given predicate. Using $(l:patterns/meta#hexcasting:halt)$(action)Charon's Gambit/$ discards the current and all remaining iotas.
